comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Well colour me (us) mortified! Thank you [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] for pointing out that we have an image of O'Sullivan's Hotel in our Lawrence Collection, and that this hotel was in Killarney, Co. Kerry! However, if any of you know an exact location, please shout and I'll add it to our Flickr map... And is this hotel still there? So, another Fergus O'Connor "unknown location" photo bites the dust (in under an hour this time!). Next time, I'll pick what I think is a really easy one, so that maybe it will turn out to be fiendishly difficult.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: In "A Week in Killarney" by Samuel Carter Hall (1843), he writes: “At Cloghreen, close to Mucross Abbey, there are two good hotels; they do not vie with the three we have named, but they are comfortable and somewhat extensive, and the charges are less than those of their rivals. “The Mucross Hotel” is close to the Abbey, and near to it is O’Sullivan’s Hotel. They are both near the foot of Mangerton, within half a mile of the Torc Waterfall – the most beautiful of the Killarney Falls – and on the direct route to the Upper Lake, and the “new line” to Kenmare. Their situation therefore is highly advantageous, being equally “convenient” to the three lakes; but “the view” is excluded by the tall trees of Mr Herbert’s demense.”

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gerryward] Wonder if the tall trees of Mr. Herbert's demesne are still standing?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Two hotels in Cloghereen on the OS 25" map: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,497746,586899,7,9 If that was O'Sullivans, it's gone now, but the pillar on the right and tree on the left may still be there! Check out Google Streetview.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I think this is the census page describing this building: Two hotels in Dromyrourk, Muckross, one with 37 windows at the front, the other 13. The proprietor of the smaller hotel was Patrick Cronin., in both 1901 and 1911 (when he was 54). That could well be him in the picture. Hey, by 1911, this hotel had 16 windows to the front! That puts this photo between 1901 and 1911.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: From www.muckrosspark.com/history-muckross The Merging of O’Sullivans Hotel & Roches Hotel 1948 In the following five years the merging of O’Sullivans Hotel and Roches Hotel created the unified property which today is known as the Muckross Park Hotel. In 1947 both properties were sold to the Murphy’s of Dublin and they decied to join both properties together. The joined properties became the complete estate as we know it today.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: I note your enthusiasts mentioning Carter Hall's A Week in Killarney. No title ever conveyed such an understatement; for it is likely that every hotelier got to know himself and his wife. As far as I remember, Fraser mentioned the Carter Halls in his book which was published in 1854 whereas A Week in Killarney was purportedly published in 1858.  Both mention seven hotels but don't agree on the seven names. I have quoted from Fraser in the History of Tourism section of the Killarney article in Wikipedia - because he appeared to be more precise in their locations.  Slater named the three hotels in 1846 along with the three hotels in Tralee. Keep the pictures coming; for there is a lot to be learned.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Gerry Ward gives 1843 as the year of origin of Carter Hall's description. If this is correct the piece he has in mind predates the 1858 Week in Killarney or it predates the piece he wrote on seven hotels, as there weren't seven hotels then. But the confusion over when or how long he spent in Killarney is interesting. He also covered such places as Glengariff, Kenmare, Waterville (where he described the hotel and the inn) Glenbeigh and the approach to Killarney from the Kenmare side. That was some week's travelling by horse carriage!                            Your picture of O'Sullivan's Hotel is excellent.

comment.author: 8214568@N08
comment._content: Don't go with my dating of "A Week In Killarney" as absolute. I had difficulty dating it with certainty, but used various sources (Oxford University, Google Books and Books & Writers) and chose '1843' as the earliest date that I found!

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content: Thanks Gerry: I have been quoting 1858 until I realized he wrote pieces on Killarney long before then, so I hope nobody took that as absolute either. If the contributors here have added to the historical confusion they have also added to the fun of viewing Flickr National Library pictures.
